Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Physics Based Modeling of Blue Jets
Award.AbstractNarration: Narrow cones of blue light that propagate upward from the top of a thundercloud were discovered during the Sprites94 aircraft campaign. Two types of blue jets (BJ) have been observed. The brief upward jets, which propagate only a few km and terminate below 26 km, were dubbed blue starters (BS), while so-called gigantic blue jets (GBJ) propagate into the mesosphere/lower ionosphere. It is widely accepted that BJ?s are produced by an upward propagating leader from thunderstorms. Some attempts have been made to describe the leader formation, including recent model of bipolar BJ. However, despite substantial progress in the theoretical understanding of this complicated phenomenon, significant puzzles remain. In fact, two outstanding problems are still unresolved and both are relevant to the laboratory leaders, as well as to the leaders formed by lightning. Namely, which mechanism governs the low propagation velocity of the leader, and how a self-consistent electric field in the streamer zone of a leader is formed. This research will focus on quantitative modeling of Blue Jets/Blue Starters/Gigantic Blue Jets. It will combine two major models, the first is an analytical and numerical study of current contraction, which determines transformation of a streamer flash into a leader, and which governs slow propagation velocity of BJ?s. The second is a model of the average electric field formed by a group of streamers in the streamer zone of a leader, which determines the BJ formation. The theoretical study will be complemented by the table top experiments that could be used for validation of the existing models. The ground based and satellite-borne optical and ultraviolet observations will attempt to validate the model predictions. Understanding the physics of BJ/BS/GBJ is not only a frontier scientific topic, but it could provide a mechanism for direct transient coupling between the ionosphere and stratosphere with implication to the global electric circuit. Potential applications include: extending fundamental knowledge in the physics of gas discharge and weakly ionized plasma by applying our model to laboratory experiments of streamer and leader breakdown, and influencing the design of powerful lasers and plasma chemical reactors through a quantitative understanding of current contraction. The program will support the education and training of the University of Maryland students in this multidisciplinary field, combining aspects of theoretical and computational plasma physics as well as gas dynamics. The study will promote collaboration between the academia and industry. It also involves broad international collaboration between Princeton University, the University of Maryland, and leading scientists from the Russian Academy of Sciences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Narrow cones of blue light that propagate upward from the top of a thundercloud were discovered during the Sprites94 aircraft campaign, now known as blue jets (BJ), the brief upward jets which propagate only a few km and terminate below 26 km were dubbed blue starters, while so-called gigantic blue jets propagate into the mesosphere/lower ionosphere. It is widely accepted that BJ’s are produced by an upward propagating leader. Some attempts were made to describe the leader formation. However, despite substantial progress in the theoretical understanding of this complicated phenomenon, significant puzzles remain.

Intellectual Merits

The major goals of the project were to develop theory and simulations for blue jets (BJ). Since they are produced by an upward propagating leader the research was focused on quantitative modeling of such leader. The project combined three major models, the first is an analytical and numerical study of current contraction, which determines the transformation of a streamer flash into a leader, and governs the slow propagation velocity of BJ’s. Two other models study formation and propagation of the streamer zone of a leader. One of the models uses simulates propagation of a group of streamers inside a discharge gap with the goal of determining the leader propagation velocity to compare with existing observations, while the other model uses fractal theory to describe development of the streamer channels that form the streamer zone of a leader. Both simulations include interference between the streamers.

Understanding the physics of BJ/BS/GBJ is not only a frontier scientific topic, but it could provide a mechanism for direct transient coupling between the ionosphere and stratosphere with   implication to the global electric circuit.

Broader Impact:

Potential applications include: extending fundamental knowledge in the physics of gas discharge and weakly ionized plasma by applying our model to laboratory experiments of streamer and leader breakdown, and influencing the design of powerful lasers and plasma chemical reactors through a quantitative understanding of current contraction. The program supported the education and training of the University of Maryland students and postdocs in this multidisciplinary field, combining aspects of theoretical and computational plasma physics as well as gas dynamics. The proposed activity promoted collaboration between the Academy and Industry. It also involved collaboration between the University of Maryland and Princeton University.

Key Outcomes

For the first time, we have developed a self-consistent model of the current contraction in air that allows a hysteresis regime of contraction. We found that the critical current for the transition from the uniform to contracted state depends on the air pressure and on the convective heat removal time. Then we used these models and simulations, as well as existing multi-instrument observations, to study the critical current for the BJ formation as a function of altitude. This allowed us to estimate the difference between starters, BJs, and gigantic BJs based on the amount of current they carry. It is illustrated by Fig. 1 which shows the current carried by a blue jet as a function of the stoppage height.

We have presented a model for the formation and propagation of the streamer zone of a leader which is an outstanding problem in the physics of electric discharges. The model is based on 2D plasma simulations which use the modified code originally developed by us. At the first step we have developed a model that simulates formation and propagation of a single positive streamer in preexisting weakly ionized plasma in the discharge gap filled by the air at the normal conditions. Then the model was generalized to describe the formation of multiple interacting positive streamers injected in the discharge gap either simultaneously or with some delay with respect to each other. It was shown in our simulations that interaction between the streamers significantly reduces their propagation velocity.  This explains why the leader, which consists of many streamers, is much slower than a single streamer formed in the same discharge gap. It was also revealed that the mean suppression velocity of the group of the streamers is determined by the inter-streamer distance.

We also developed a model that describes the formation and propagation of the streamer zone of a leader using fractal theory. We studied the fractal dimension of the bunch of streamer channels emitted by BJ and GBJ, at different altitude and under the varying electric ?eld. Such similarity analysis has been done in three steps: ?rst we described the dendritic structure of streamers in corona discharge applying the fractal theory. Then using our fractal model and the data from existing laboratory experiments we obtained the fractal dimension of the branching streamer channels. Finally, the model was validated by the observations of BJ available from the literature.
